column4: hmm, little wireless issue - two laptops, both the same except one on intrepid one on jaunty. wireless network is on WPA2, I can't change that. Intrepid connects fine, Jaunty fails every time
have you tried to watch "tail -f /var/log/wpa_supplicant.log" (or similar named) while connecting?
no, though someone else suggested trying a wpa_supplicant, which actually crashed jaunty entirely, and forced me to fresh install
ubuntu is using wpa_supplicant for connecting to wpa2 networks, afaik
I can try reinstalling yet again, but since it's a fresh install, I assumed it'd work as it does on the intrepid one - right out of the box, no issues
yes, it should... try watching, what error causes wpa_supplicant to not connect
not sure, I'm using the gnome network manager applet, it tries connecting, asks for the password for the network several times, then disconnects, nothing extra
as i said, try: "tail -f /var/log/wpa_supplicant.log", disable wireless networking, enable it, then connect and see, what is added to the log file
alright, back in a few with result
returns CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECTED - Disconnect event - remove keys then Authentication with 00:00:00:00:00:00 timed out.
hm, that's not much... does the ap accept the mac of the wlan device?
you could also try to watch the output of "sudo iwconfig" (call it multiple times while connecting), to see, if the device get associated with the ap and gets a key
is it the same network device, that is used? or only a similar? every network device has a different mac address burnt into
it's the same network device on both, though I have third computer which has a different device also on jaunty, that fails too
it does appear to get a key and connect, but that's as far as it seems to go, it seems to me like it's not sending the network password
does it expect dhcp which is perhaps not there? you could also try to run wpa_supplicant manually to get more debugging output and find out what causes the problem
I don't think so, how exactly do you run it manually, and I'll have a look and try to find out

you have to tell the running wpa_supplicant instance to not configure you wlan device (disable wireless?), then setup a simple wpa_supplicant.conf configuration file (google will find many examples) and run wpa_supplicant as root with the options for device, mode and so on (wpa_supplicant --help will tell possible options)
thanks, hopefully this will solve it
